subtopics.content: • India’s women’s cricket team commenced their T20I series against England on July 1–12 across Bristol and Lord's.

topic: 2. India vs England Test Series – July 2025

subtopics.subtopic: India play second to fourth Tests
subtopics.content: • India contested the 2nd (2–6 July), 3rd (10–14 July), and 4th (23–27 July) Tests of the England tour.
• Indian shuttlers including Satwiksairaj & Chirag and other players featured in the qualification rounds of the Macau Open Super 300 event.
• Divya Deshmukh triumphed over Koneru Humpy in the final of the 2025 FIDE Women's Chess World Cup in Batumi.
• Nihal Sarin battled Anish Giri to stay in the 2025 eSports World Cup; Arjun Erigaisi joined the quarterfinals.
• India vs Pakistan match at World Championship of Legends 2025 was cancelled after Indian legends pulled out.
• India Legends reached WCL semifinals, but a potential match vs Pakistan raised concerns over cancellation once again.
• Indian athletes participated across global events—cricket, badminton, table tennis, archery, para-sports—throughout July.
• July featured Wimbledon, Canada Open (badminton), FIFA Club World Cup, eSports World Cup, and FISU University Games, with Indians in action.
• Prithvi Shaw left the Mumbai Cricket Association and signed with Maharashtra ahead of the 2025-26 domestic season.
• At the Neeraj Chopra Classic, the two-time Olympic medallist won gold before heading to the Diamond League season.
• Swimmers like Sajan Prakash and Aryan Nehra represented India in the 2025 World Aquatics Championships in Singapore (July 11–Aug 3).
• Indian athletes contributed to India’s medal haul—2 golds, 5 silvers, 5 bronzes—at FISU World University Games in Germany.0}
• India contested four Test matches during their England tour, spanning the entire month of July.1}
• Indian paddlers featured in global table tennis events like WTT Star Contender during July.2}
• Indian athletes competed in Diamond League events—including Monaco, Eugene, London—through July.3}
• Indians took part in Asian championships in archery and U-15/U-20 wrestling in July.4}

subtopics.subtopic: Indians at Esports Cup in Riyadh
subtopics.content: • The Esports World Cup 2025 was underway in Riyadh through August, with Indian teams competing.5}

subtopics.subtopic: From tennis to rugby to golf
subtopics.content: • July’s schedule spanned Wimbledon, rugby tests, British Open golf, MotoGP, Tour de France, Fencing, and more.6}
• A comprehensive calendar featured global tournaments and disciplines from tennis to cricket and athletics to motorsport.7}

topic: 21. India Women vs England T20s – Early July

subtopics.content: • India’s women’s cricket team played T20Is in England, competing across Bristol and Lord's venues during early July.

topic: 22. India Men’s Test Series vs England

subtopics.content: • The Indian men’s team played the 2nd (2–6 July), 3rd (10–14 July), and 4th (23–27 July) Tests during their England tour.
• Indian players took part in doubles and qualifying rounds at Wimbledon, held from June 30 to July 13.
• Indian shuttlers featured in the BWF Canada Open Super 300 tournament held from July 1 to 6 in Ontario.
• Indian paddlers participated in WTT’s US Smash (Las Vegas, 3–13 July), WTT Lagos, and Buenos Aires events.
• Indian archers took part in the Archery World Cup in Madrid (8–13 July), and shooters competed in ISSF Shotgun World Cups in Italy.

subtopics.subtopic: Neeraj and others in Diamond League
subtopics.content: • Indian athletes featured in Diamond League meets: Eugene (5 July), Monaco (11 July), and London (19 July).
• Pro Volleyball League Season 3 began preparations, featuring new international players and format ahead of an August kickoff.
• Young stars like R. Praggnanandhaa represented India at the prestigious Norway Chess World Cup starting July 18.
• The Esports World Cup took place in Riyadh (8 July to 24 August), with Indian gamers across Valorant, COD 6, and Online Chess.

topic: 31. Divya Deshmukh Wins Chess World Cup

subtopics.content: • Divya Deshmukh overcame Koneru Humpy in the FIDE Women’s Chess World Cup final in Batumi.
• Sprinter Animesh Kujur clocked a national 100m record of 10.18 seconds at the Dromia International Sprint Meet in Greece.0}
• Christian Horner was sacked as Red Bull F1 Team Principal during July.1}

topic: 34. Jofra Archer Returns to Lord’s Test

subtopics.content: • Jofra Archer was recalled to England’s XI for the Lord’s Test versus India.2}
• On July 31, highlights included India vs England Test, U-19 squad announcement, and PKL Season 12 schedule.3}
• Performances across athletics, cricket, and badminton were featured in live updates on India Sports Day.4}
• July hosted Wimbledon, Canada and Macau Badminton Opens, World Fencing Champs, Open Golf, Archery, and ISSF contests.5}
• Indian athletes participated in tennis, badminton, archery, para-sport, and cricket across continents in early July.6}
• Indian players contested the qualification rounds at the Macau Open (Super 300) starting late July.7}
• Analysis includes India’s participation in World Games, Fencing, Open Golf, and other July–August mega-events.8}

• At the 2025 Para-Archery Asian Championships in Beijing, India's women’s compound team (Sheetal Devi, Jyoti) beat China 148-143 to win gold.
• Harvinder Singh and Bhawna secured mixed recurve gold via a dramatic 5-4 shoot-off.

• Anahat Singh won the Asian U19 Squash Championship, defeating Hong Kong’s Cheung TC 3-0 (11-7, 11-2, 11-8).
• In the U17 category, Aryaveer Dewan secured the boys’ title—both historic wins for India.
• 14-year-old Vaibhav Suryavanshi smashed the fastest known century in Youth ODIs, reaching 100 in just 52 balls against England.
• The India Champions team pulled out of their semifinal clash against Pakistan Champions in the World Championship of Legends, advancing Pakistan to the final.
• Indian athletes featured across tournaments globally including cricket, badminton, archery, swimming, table tennis, wrestling, chess, football, and athletics throughout July.
• July hosted critical events like Wimbledon, Diamond League (Eugene, Monaco, London), World Aquatics Champs, Asian Junior Championships, Archery World Cup, and Esports WC.
• The FIDE Women’s Chess World Cup ran from July 5 to 29 in Batumi, with strong Indian participation including the eventual champion.
• Indian juniors competed in the World Junior Squash Championships; table tennis stars featured in WTT Contender events in Lagos, Buenos Aires, and Brazil.
• The Indian women’s team played T20Is and ODIs in England while the men’s Test series continued with 2nd to 4th matches in July.
• The Neeraj Chopra Classic took place in Bengaluru on July 5. Indian swimmers competed in the World Aquatics Championships in Singapore from July 11 to August 3.
